item.content:encoded:
The Phase 1 live prototype, at Bradford 19th-21st of July, was a great success. Creating a fully formed, fully immersive experience, while testing the storyline, various activities and experiences with a live public audience (target range 7-12 and their families) and collaborative delivery team.

See pictures of Space Plague Bradford here: https://flic.kr/s/aHsmFoNq11

The co-design process, to date, has involved:

  • 60 Year 5 pupils, and 6 teachers from Haberdashers Aske’s Temple Grove Free School in South East London.
  • 20 Final Year and 2 Year 2 Product Design and Engineering students from Middlesex University.
  • 2 MSc Creative Technology students from Middlesex University.
  • 4 BSc Film and TV Production students from the University of Greenwich.
  • 8 Design, Engineering and Film Academics and Technical Tutors from Middlesex University and the University of Greenwich.
  • 3 Scientists from the Structural Genomics Consortium
  • 4 Scientists and Public Engagement staff from the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory – Diamond Light Source and ISIS Neutron and Muon Source.
  • 1 Scientist from the British Ecological Society
  • 1 Independent Public Engagement/Science/Performance expert.
  • 1 Science academic from Birmingham University.
  • 3 Professional Actors/Performers.
  • 15 Bradford community volunteer facilitators, through the National Science and Media Museum.
  • 3 Bradford engineering volunteers.
  • 4 SMASHfestUK Core Team.

The rich range of experience, experiences, perspectives and creativity that this collaborative group have brought together, and the training in co-design and immersive experience development and delivery that SMASHfestUK team have facilitated, has ensured that Phase 1 at Bradford was both successful as an experience in itself, and as the building block prototype for the next Phases.

‘Space Plague’, is a phased co-designed experience exploring Immersive Narrative Embodiment effects amongst communities underserved by STEM and Arts informal education and underrepresented in STEM and Arts education and careers.

Funded by the Science and Technology Facilities Council ‘Nucleus Award’, the Royal Academy of Engineering ‘INGENIOUS’ and the British Science Association, and is a partnership between SMASHfestUK CIC, Middlesex University, the University of Greenwich, the Rutherford Appleton Labs – Diamond Light Source and ISIS Neutron and Muon Source, the Structural Genomics Consortium at the University of Oxford, the British Ecological Society and the National Science and Media Museum.

The project will run across three Phases, with events in Bradford July 2019, Deptford February 2020, and Bradford October 2020. There will be ongoing Co-Design, Co-Production and Co-Delivery cycles throughout the process.

item.content:encoded:
‘Space Plague’, is SMASHfestUK’s new phased co-designed experience programme. It will explore Immersive Narrative Embodiment effects amongst communities underserved by STEM and Arts informal education and underrepresented in STEM and Arts education and careers.

We are lucky to have gained funding from the Science and Technology Facilities Council ‘Nucleus Award’, the Royal Academy of Engineering ‘INGENIOUS’, the British Science Association and the Arts Council, England. The project is a partnership between SMASHfestUK CIC, Middlesex University, the University of Greenwich, Central St Martin’s UAL, the Rutherford Appleton Labs – Diamond Light Source and ISIS Neutron and Muon Source, the Structural Genomics Consortium at the University of Oxford, the British Ecological Society and the National Science and Media Museum.

The project will run across three Phases, with ongoing co-design workshops with partners and community groups, and events in Bradford July 2019, Deptford February 2020, and Bradford October 2020. There will be ongoing Co-Design, Co-Production and Co-Delivery cycles throughout the process.

item.title: Astro-Commanders Wanted!
item.dc:creator: Lindsay
item.description: Ever wondered what it feels to lead a group of space travellers through an adventure? Ever thought about defending the human kind from an impending cosmo-threat? This might be your chance! We are over the moon to have been awarded funding from the UKRI and UKSFN to launch a new […]
item.content:encoded:
Ever wondered what it feels to lead a group of space travellers through an adventure? Ever thought about defending the human kind from an impending cosmo-threat? This might be your chance!

We are over the moon to have been awarded funding from the UKRI and UKSFN to launch a new immersive sci/art project with young people aged 11-14 in South East London. How, you ask? The SMASHfestUK way of course!

We will take over two venues here in the South East London (galactic) System during October half-term to bring an immersive and out-of-this world experience to the young people from the local planets … but we need your help!

This adventure can’t take place without talented astro-commanders to help the younger travellers during their journey.

Who are these astro-commanders, you ask? Astronomers, Cosmologists, Physicists, Space Engineers, Astrobiologists and anyone working within the space field!

What would astro-commanders do?

  • Collaborate with a group of local young people and artists to create a challenging activity based on their work and/or research in the period prior to the event.
  • Help lead a group of young people through the challenges of space travel during the two immersive events.
  • Commit to 5 days in total (expenses paid by prior agreement) between September (2 half days, 23rd and 26th of September) and October (1 half-day TBD for training, 2 full days – 25th and 28th of October). Exact days to be defined soon. Time commitment can be discussed, so please don’t hesitate to contact me if you are interested. 

What will the astro-commanders get from the project?

  • Each commander will participate in a bespoke training session from the SMASHfestUK team covering public engagement, communication skills, community engagement and storytelling for scientists.
  • A platform to discuss their work and/or research with young people from South East London within an informal setting.
  • The opportunity to develop an engagement activity based on their work and/or research with close support from the award-winning SMASHfestUK team!

Who would be the perfect astro-commander?  

  • Based in or can easily travel to London/Greater London (expenses paid by prior agreement).
  • Interested in the Arts, STEM and Cultural Engagement.
  • Willing to engage the young people involved with the storyline created (might include: making top-notch space noises, wearing an astro-fascinator, using space-related puns and more… Training will be provided if this is outside your comfort zone!).
  • Able to commit to 5 days between September and the end of October (3 half days in September/Early October, 2 full days in October w/c 22nd) – all expenses paid by prior agreement. 
  • Happy to work with others as part of a team.

Want to know more or want to join the mission?
Contact the Mission Producer, Paolo, on paolo@smashfestuk.com with subject “Astro-commander”.

item.content:encoded:
Young Explainers are 16-18 year olds with an interest in Science and Engineering who also enjoy art and design. Responsibilities of a young explainer are to create exhibits and hands on activities for the festival, explain the science and technology behind the event and interview visitors to collect feedback.

My name is Roisin and I am a young explainer at this year’s SMASHfestUK: FLOOD! 2018. I heard about this opportunity through my school and, since then, I meet up once a week with other young explainers from my school. For this festival, we are focusing on three topics: Living in Space, Combustion and Water Rockets. As a team, we discuss ideas and aspects of the topic we want to explain and create an interactive presentation for the event.


As a young explainer I have been given new opportunities to lear and develop new skills. Working to create an exhibition from scratch for the festival is something I haven’t done before, and is a big responsibility. You have to work as a team with the other young explainers to assign roles best fit to their skills and take into consideration everyone’s ideas to create a successful event. Time management is key. I have had to research, develop ideas and made sure the showcase is clear and relevant to the target audience, young children and parents.

To sign up and help volunteer at SMASHfestUK FLOOD! 2018 event you can click here or visit the Get Involved page on our website!

SMASHfestUK is really excited about working with TfL for this year’s festival!

item.title: We Did Start The Fire!
item.dc:creator: Lindsay
item.description: SMASHfestUK is largely aimed at families and young people – but that doesn’t mean we can’t spice things up in the evening! Join us at The Albany Theatre on the 16th February at 7pm for our fundraiser show ‘We Did Start The Fire’ – Grown ups only! We’ve put together […]
item.content:encoded:
SMASHfestUK is largely aimed at families and young people – but that doesn’t mean we can’t spice things up in the evening! Join us at The Albany Theatre on the 16th February at 7pm for our fundraiser show ‘We Did Start The Fire’ – Grown ups only!

We’ve put together a line-up of fantastic performers for a SMASHfestUK first – an adult-only show, which is, in fact two shows for the price of one! Great value, and great entertainment for 2017’s SMASHfestUK Fundraiser. We’re heading off on tour to communities across the UK this year, and funds raised at this show will help us take SMASHfestUK to more people and ensure that it comes back for 2018.

We’ve devised two shows to keep you on your toes, firstly Shrinking Space will be taking you on an immersive and interactive theatre experience with “Operation Doomsday – Chapter Supervolcano” What happens when the Supervolcano erupts? Can you save the world… or whats left of it?

Then our second performance will be a variety show presented by Helen Arney; featuring music, rapping, explosions and even the occasional hula hoop! We will even be squeezing a bar break in! What more could you need?

Although we try to keep SMASHfestUK free during the day, we are suggesting a donation of £10 or whatever you feel like paying! This will help us take SMASHfestUK on the road, and keep it going next year!
